Emmett.Action: Wakes quickly, retrieves his gun, and shoots accurately to kill the intruder who burst into his shack.
Maintains composure under heavy fire, strategically follows the gunmen's positions on the walls and controls his shooting to stop an attacker’s progress.
Calms the nervous pinto horse after the fight.
Looks down at the dead man outside without apparent malice or satisfaction.
Uses lethal force to defend himself without hesitation.
Finds a severely dehydrated man in the desert, gives him water, cares for him at camp.
Nods to confirm the rifle is loaded, implying trustworthiness to Paden.
Takes responsibility to tend the horses, allowing Paden to enter the store.
Flips Paden a coin to cover expenses, demonstrating generosity and support.
Compliments Paden's horse sincerely, showing attention to what Paden values.
Gives Paden an amused look when Paden complains about missing his hat, indicating shared understanding or kindness.
Provides straightforward, neutral answers about Turley without engaging in much detail or enthusiasm.
Gives a knowing, amused look at Paden's fussing, showing awareness and social intelligence.
Carefully unties his two horses and prepares to leave deliberately, indicating purposeful behavior.
Responds vaguely about Turley, indicating either cautiousness or lack of detailed knowledge.
Invites Paden to ride along with him as far as Turley, sensing his hesitation and offering companionship.
Offers to let Paden ride along to Turley, showing situational awareness and leadership.
Leads the way confidently into Turley despite the town's unpromising appearance.
Notices the construction of the gallows and the settlers' interest, indicating attentiveness and awareness.
Correctly identifies that he is not who Hobart expects and calmly clarifies his identity, showing clear-headedness.

Questions the waitress assertively to gather information about a suspicious person, showing initiative and attention to detail.

Waves a chicken leg slightly at the Third Man to signal 'Stay out of it', effectively discouraging him from joining the fight.
Observes the situation carefully and asks Paden to clarify which way he means regarding fairness, indicating attentiveness and thoughtful consideration.

Expresses determination to rescue his brother despite the difficulty.

Responds to parted ways with no hard feelings.
Makes light, joking response about buying a drink, showing friendly and easygoing interaction.
Acknowledges the difficulty of breaking his brother out of jail but commits to doing it anyway because of family loyalty.
Plans to continue to California with his brother and visit their sister, showing a clear goal and purpose.
Accepts Paden’s decision to not help with the jailbreak without argument, showing emotional intelligence and pragmatism.
Engages in light banter about buying drinks despite knowing Paden has no money, showing confidence and social ease.
Moves to the dead man, unbuckles the gunbelt, and puts the gun in the holster calmly.
Loiters by the door during the sheriff's office scene, does not provoke confrontation, states he hasn't done anything when threatened to be thrown in jail.
Accepts the sheriff's order to leave town before the hanging without arguing.
Moves to the dead man, unbuckles the gunbelt, and pulls it free of the body; picks up the bone-handled Colt and puts it in the holster.
Loiters by the door as Sheriff Langston settles himself, calmly replies that he hasn't done anything, and responds confidently to Langston's order to leave town.
Hesitates and shows confusion about rescuing Jake, questioning the purpose of saving him.
Takes keys, holsters gun, opens cell door, and goes inside to cut Jake down, showing decisive action and practical approach.
Is startled and loses control when Jake sputters to life, raising the knife threateningly and almost firing his gun reflexively.

Rides into view leading horses to help Jake and Paden during a firefight, calls out encouragement to Jake.

Rides confidently with the others, identifies with the group run out of town, and approaches the wagon train calmly with his companions.
Warns Hobart and settlers that the territory is dangerous and urges them to get the women and children out for their safety.

Recognizes the danger of staying in the territory with women and children and advises to get them out.
Questions the presence of Hobart's group and challenges their assumptions about the area.

Uses fast talking and an attempt at friendliness (offering his hand) to de-escalate a dangerous situation.

Despite being in a vulnerable position and outnumbered, he maintains composure and attempts to manipulate the situation assertively.

Warns Dawson to get down as danger may be imminent.

Block.Action: Initially hesitates to help Jake, questioning the point of saving him.
Despite hesitation, uses keys to open cell and attempts to cut Jake down from hanging.
